projects.title: Heart vector-mediated gene therapy: towards a clinically applicable cure for inherited cardiomyopathies
projects.description: The only way to cure a genetic disease is to correct the disease-causing mutation. Thus, ongoing research is focused on developing gene therapies to correct these mutations. Building upon our recent advances in understanding the complex genetics behind cardiomyopathies and viral vector-mediated therapies, we aim to provide a) the first preclinical proof-of-concept (PoC) therapy for PLN R14del-induced cardiomyopathy and, in doing so, b) gather knowledge and assemble a technology toolbox permitting accelerating therapeutic development for inherited cardiomyopathies. To this end, we will perform head-to-head comparisons of different gene therapy technologies in (i) an in vitro model based on PLN R14del patient-derived iPSC-CMs, and (ii) humanized mouse and porcine models carrying the PLN R14del mutation

contributors.headline: Scientist at Batavia Biosciences l Cell & Gene Therapy I Drug Development I Biomarkers | Assays | Quality & Compliance

projects.title: Cardiovascular Moonshot RegMed XB: Regeneration of the human heart
projects.description: The cardiovascular moonshot of RegMed XB is a comprehensive program based on the concept that we should be able to create a cardiac (re-)generative therapy that suits best the individual patient. One approach is to restore the heart function outside of the body (ex vivo). The advantage of this method is that we can solely treat the heart and assess cardiac function during treatment. During the time the heart is outside the body, the body will be connected to a heart-lung machine. After restoring the heart, it will be re-implanted. With this approach, gene therapy to cure hereditary diseases will also become possible. The researchers aim to stimulate the body’s own regenerative capacity including, for example, improving the contractility and perfusion of the heart muscle, repair, or replacement of coronary arteries and heart valves.

contributors.headline: Scientist at Batavia Biosciences l Cell & Gene Therapy I Drug Development I Biomarkers | Assays | Quality & Compliance

projects.title: Development of clinical prediction models for cardiac allograft vasculopathy and late graft failure in heart transplant recipients- A clinical Study
projects.description: Most of the survival improvement in heart transplant recipients in the past three decades is related to mortality reduction during the first post-transplant year. Mortality beyond 1 year after transplant has only slightly declined for patients transplanted in the past 20 years. After the first year, cardiac allograft vasculopathy (CAV) and late graft failure are the most important cause of death in heart transplant recipients. On one hand, this project is directed at the development of prediction models of CAV and late graft failure. On the other hand, the objective is to improve our understanding of the pathophysiology of late graft failure and its relation with epicardial CAV, microvascular CAV, and low-grade myocardial injury.

contributors.headline: Scientist at Batavia Biosciences l Cell & Gene Therapy I Drug Development I Biomarkers | Assays | Quality & Compliance

projects.title: High-density lipoprotein-targeted therapies for heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF).
projects.description: Heart failure is the cardiovascular epidemic of the 21st century.  This syndrome is a growing public health problem, the leading cause of hospitalization, and a major cause of mortality. Plasma high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol levels and levels of its major apolipoprotein (apo), apo A-I, are inversely correlated with the incidence of coronary heart disease. HDLs exert divergent functions that include actions mediated by HDL receptor ecto-F1-ATPase coupled to purinergic P2Y receptors, scavenger receptor class B, type I (SR-BI), and/or receptor activation by HDL cargo molecules. These pleiotropic properties offer perspectives for new therapeutic areas for HDL-targeted interventions. The general objective of this project is to study the effect of administration of apo A-I Milano/phospholipid complexes (HDL Milano) and hepatocyte-directed AAV8-mediated apo A-I gene transfer in murine models of HFpEF.

profile_positions.description:
• Pre-clinical development of gene therapies.
• Responsible for the in-house and outsourced non-clinical activities with project-specific methods (GxP). 
• Generation of (qualified & on-time) pre-clinical data to support future clinical development of leads and products. 
• Ensures that external contractors adhere to predefined quality standards and timelines. 
• Coordinating with internal manufacturing departments in order to deliver the qualified study materials on time.
• Provide scientific and operational input to project teams to achieve the expectations
• Setting up relevant hiPSC / mouse models/ Porcine models for disease modeling
profile_positions.title: Scientist, Non-Clinical Development

profile_positions.description:
• Design, planning, and budgeting of multiple in-vitro and in-vivo studies for the screening and development of biologics against range of diseases
• Setup and maintenance of the research plan
• Provide scientific input for target selection and efficacy testing
• Writing and reviewing R&D reports, SOPs, and work instructions
• Subject matter expert for gene therapy and animal research
• Design and management of all in-house animal experimentation
• Writing of license for the Central Authority for Scientific Procedures on Animals (CCD) and 
 work protocols for animal experimentation procedures
• Article 9 responsible for in-house in vivo experiments and GMO regulations
profile_positions.title: Research Scientist

profile_positions.description: Research and Development. Innovating. Supervising. Troubleshooting. Scientific Writing and Communication.
profile_positions.title: Research Scientist

profile_positions.description:
• Developed novel murine models of heart failure, diabetes, and metabolic disease
• Executed pre-clinical and clinical projects with successful HDL-targeted therapies
• Established invasive pressure-volume loop (gold standard) for cardiac function analysis in murine models
• Showed therapeutic efficacy of recombinant protein and AAV-gene therapy in various animal models of heart failure and metabolic disease.
• Developed a clinical prediction model for heart transplant recipients
• Represented our research group in many international meetings and published more than 15 high-impact research articles
profile_positions.title: Doctor of  Biomedical Sciences (PhD)

profile_positions.description:
• Investigated peptide-mediated therapeutics in cancer and infectious diseases. 
• Screened novel cell-penetrating and antimicrobial peptide drugs using high-throughput screening assays.
• Planned and executed assays for dose-dependent and the cytotoxic response of peptide drugs.
• Confocal microscopy, qPCR, cell culture,  and Facs analysis (FACS)
• Wrote scientific papers and technical documents (deviations, procedures, protocols, reports), involving evaluation and implementation of the standard operating procedure.
• Research led to the filing of an American Patent: Agrobacterium derived cell-penetrating peptides as Nano-carriers (PCT/IN2017/050331).
profile_positions.title: Researcher
